Entry.1: Still at Brulooze (Mt. Kemmel) Fritz putting over some big shells, some landing near railhead. Two shells landed 200 yds from our Camp, setting fire to two barns & just missing farmhouse.
Entry.2:
27. Loading at 5 a.m. Orders to pack & be ready for early shift next day.

Everything packed except blankets and stowed on lorries 6 p.m. Orders to dump all boxes and spare kit. Blankets & kitbag & equipment only allowed.
Entry.3: Loaded at 5 a.m. Kits & bags spread over the various lorries carrying rations. Left Brulooze at 9.30 trekking down through Steenwercke, Merville, Lillers, St. Venant, St. Pol to 1 mile outside Doullens. Very cold bleek day and dust from proceeding lorries stung our eyes. Lorries proceed to various brigades I being on one that went to Vauchelles, 12 kilometres from Doullens. Unloaded, parked and slept on lorry for the night. One Brigade had to retire two villages to dump rations.
Entry.4: Column stationed at Pommera. Arrived back at Column at 11 a.m. Loading at Warlincourt. Camped in tents outside an estaminet and at back of a church.
Entry.6:
Went to Belle Eglise to load at 10 a.m.

but train not in till 1 p.m.
Entry.7: still camped at Pommera, but proceeded thro' Doullens to Vignacourt to load. Great congestion in yard.
Entry.8: Struck camp at 7 a.m. and proceeded via Doullens and Picquigy to Ailly-Sur-Somme to load. Later pitched camp at St. Saveur, 2 k.m. away. Three of us billetted.
Entry.9: Went to Amiens to load at 10 a.m. City deserted and being shelled.
Entry.10: Railway yard shelled. One of our Section hit in stomach with part of a shell, subsequently dying of wounds. Another taken to hospital with the shock but recovered.
Entry.11: Loading again at Ailly-sur-Somme at midday. Nice warm day.
Entry.12: 18-19-20. Very cold and unseasonable weather. Snow fall during the dayof
Entry.13: and much snow and frost on ground on morning of
Entry.16: Loaded at 6 a.m. at Ailly, and after dinner packed up at short notice and proceeded to Raineville Rd, between Allonville & Poulainville, near Amiens.
Entry.17: Loading at Poulainville at 8 a.m. An aerodrome not far away & much stunting including flying at few feet above the ground and tree tops. Under canvas & dug in
Entry.18: 1-14. Epidemic of sickness in the Section resembling influenza.
Entry.22: Still camped at Poulainville, but loading at Ailly-Sur-Somme at 9 a.m.
Entry.23: Four of our balloons brought down in as many minutes.
Entry.25: Loaded at Ailly at 9.30 a.m. At 7 p.m. proceeded by car to Saleuse to await supply train & figures, which afterwards went on to La Motte Brebiere. After working at figures proceeded by lorry without lights to Railhead. Our two grocery trucks off the line & alteration in figures., All traffic held up by the passage of several tanks. Much congestion. Pack train drew out at daybreak, and Section arrived back at camp at 7 a.m.
Entry.26: Not necessary to go to Saleuse for figures, as Railhead detachment at La Motte.
Entry.28: Loading at Corbie. Under canvas amongst apple trees in ruined Corbie. The five Australian Divisions loaded at Corbie this day under the only Ausie Railhead Detachment in France - the only occasion when such has happened.
Entry.29:
Now loading at Villers-Brettoneux which is in abject ruins. R.S.O's office

in room of a big house, with pictures still on the wall, carpet on floor, and great sideboard, hardly marked by shot or shrapnell. Loading at 7 a.m.
Entry.30: Proceeded to La Flaque to load at 7 a.m. passing thro' territory recently held by Fritz.
Entry.31: Reveille at 4 a.m. Kits &c loaded on lorries, and proceeded to railhead to draw at 7 a.m. Camped in dugouts,mostly boarded-up, floored and fixed bunks, all substantially built by Huns, who were not long in occupation. Ammunition dugouts filled with explosives, and dumps in adjacent fields. Large German Engineers' Dump, near by, with large quantities of materials untouched. Buildings mostly demolished, and other materials destroyed by fire and shell-fire.
Entry.33: Went to see large 15.2" German gun in ruins. Disabled and burnt tanks here and there. Parties at work salvaging materials and burying dead.
Entry.34: Loading at Froisay, further forward. 7 a.m. Train not in till 10 a.m. on two mornings. Railyard in ruins, large mine craters in middle of yard, rails bent and twisted in the air, and all buildings laid waste and burnt.
Entry.35: Reveille at 4 a.m. struck camp andproceeded to La Chapelette to load, near Peronne. Train not in till 11 a.m. Pitched camp while raining and blowing hard. Passed country that had already been fought over. All shell-craters like a face pock-marked with fever. Railyard much damaged by retiring Germans. Iron railway bridge near-by demolished and several bridges across canals and the river, blown up. Passed a village almost entirely disappeared, Only the cobbled street marked out its site.
Entry.36: Sawa Super Gotha brought down in flames, his burning flares giving out coloured lights. Presently another brought down & countryside lit up with the exploding bombs. Australians heard cheering.
Entry.37: Another Hun aeroplane brought down in flames.
Entry.38: 16-17 (night) Tent blown down and raining heavily. Some storm.
Entry.39: Loading at Cortigny at 8 a.m. passed through ruined Peronneen route.
Entry.40: New Scale of Rations in force. Engine derailed & train arrived at 2 p.m.
